messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:04): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: thanks. I kinda wish we had a clear direction on <style scoped>: remove from spec ASAP or implement in browsers ASAP
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:04): oh, is it controversial?
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:05): I love it for code examples ‚Äî everything bundled into one figure
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:05): i don't think it's controversial, it's just low priority and probably non-trivial to implement (especially scoped @-rules)
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:08): yeah, that‚Äôs true. I‚Äôm just using it with an id hook, so implementation isn‚Äôt really so important for me

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:08): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: maybe the simplest thing to do at the moment is have an assertion that bans <style scoped> on the basis that it's not implemented anywhere yet so should not be used yet
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:09): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: is it actually harmful tho? it‚Äôs just added to head styles, no?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:10): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: it's harmful if sites start depending on styles being applied to the whole document
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:10): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: because then the feature can't be implemented without breaking those sites
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:10): apparently this has already happened with "use strict";
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:12): I was thinking to write about it for HTML5Doctor, and say to use with an id hook until there‚Äôs browser support
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:12): i'd wait with recommending use of new features until they're implemented
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:13): well, more if you use it, use it like this. I take your point, but I think ppl will find and use it regardless
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:13): i'm frankly surprised that we haven't had any problems with <article> and friends
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:13): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: good points; please file bugs!

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (10:15): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: regardless of which way you decide to jump, the current error for style scoped is a bit confusing, so a warning or more accurate admonition would help

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (11:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think the spec needs to define what a document is. It needs a definition or a pointer to a definition. Many people get confused between syntax and document.
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (11:52): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: AFAIK the whatwg doesn't have a bug tracking system
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:53): 952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6: html wg does, there's a comment box in the whatwg spec to use it
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (11:55): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, I know, but some people prefer not to deal with the w3c so the whatwg should provide some sort of alternative.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:56): ah, ok. the alternative in whatwg land is <email/> i guess
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (11:56): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, I'll sort something out
